primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The journey of the human soul from self-sufficiency and 'shrewdness' back to a state of dependence on God through the act of returning to a place of spiritual encounter.

tekstueel_bewijs: Jacob, you see, was a rascal...
He decided he would go back to live at Bethel
He would admit that he was not smart, he needed God
make life's journey a victory march
he was never going to have peace
where the light had broken on his pathway
The old fear came over Jacob again. Finally he began seeing it!
Things were never going to work out for him... because he had wandered so far
God will deliver me, God will guide
he needed God if he was going to make life's journey a victory march
God will help me, God will deliver me
his old wily shrewdness came back to him
the allurements of the world and the blandishments of pleasure
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is primarily Jacob's own 'slickness' and the 'minor slip-ups' in his strategy, rather than an ontological state of sin.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The ethical/ritual cleanup required to facilitate the return to God.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer/Jacob
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The human must 'put away strange gods' and 'be clean' as a prerequisite or immediate accompaniment to the primary goal of reaching Bethel.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God appeared and spoke to Jacob
God draws us back to Bethel
God will hear, God will answer me
voorbeelden_mens_subject: He decided he would go back
Jacob called on the God of his fathers
We can go back in Spirit and start over

voorbeelden: we must not confuse sentimental feeling
Let us put aside the idols
he still wanted to go home
he decided he would go back
realize that it never is going to work out until God works it out
A person can rise above circumstances

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon is a 'Recruitment' narrative. It focuses on awakening the hearer's desire (Vouloir) to return to a previous state of piety.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Movement from S1 (initial Bethel) to ~S1 (shrewdness/forgetting), leading to S2 (distress), and finally a call to return to S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Resolution is achieved through human decision: 'He decided he would go back.'
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Moderate. S2 is seen as 'restlessness' and 'things not working out' rather than divine judgment.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon uses the name of God frequently, the 'engine' is anthropocentric. Jacob (the human) is the Subject who must act, decide, and return. God is the Object/Destination or the Helper, but rarely the primary Subject of the active verbs of salvation.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: it never is going to work out until God works it out [implies human must stop first]
He decided he would go back to live at Bethel

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: God appeared and spoke to Jacob

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Jacob is used as a psychological and moral archetype for the hearer's own journey of self-correction.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: A theocentric reading would focus on God's faithfulness to His covenant with Jacob despite Jacob's shrewdness, emphasizing that God brought Jacob back, rather than Jacob deciding to return.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Pressure to perform a 'return' or 'decision' to fix their life.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Synergism where human decision is the catalyst for divine action.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The narrative is very coherent but follows a 'Hero's Journey' structure rather than a 'Rescue' structure.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'God draws us' and 'We must arise and go'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: He would admit that he was not smart, he needed God

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon assumes the hearer has the inherent power (Pouvoir) to return if they have the will (Vouloir).

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is characterized as 'shrewdness' or 'wily' behavior that leads to 'unforeseen errors in judgment' rather than total depravity.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon functions as a call to human action where God is the reward for a successful return. The actantial Subject is consistently 'We' or 'Jacob'.

subject_herpositionering.huidige_probleem: The hearer is the one who must 'go back' to get God.
subject_herpositionering.voorgestelde_herpositionering: Make God the Subject who pursues Jacob even in his shrewdness.
subject_herpositionering.voorbeeld_revisie: Instead of 'Jacob decided to go back,' use 'God's relentless grace finally cornered Jacob, compelling him to return.'

identificatie_herstel.voorgestelde_identificatie: Hearer as the 'Receiver' of God's call.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that Bethel was God's idea (Gen 35:1) before it was Jacob's.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Focus on how God enables the return when we are too 'shrewd' to save ourselves.

tegenstander_intensivering.voorgestelde_intensivering: Present sin as a power that Jacob cannot escape by being 'smarter'.
tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: To make grace necessary rather than just helpful.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.probleem: The 'Secondary Program' (cleaning up) is presented as a condition for the 'Primary Program' (meeting God).
narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: God meets Jacob (Primary), which then empowers Jacob to put away idols (Secondary).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: The sermon is rhetorically powerful and relatable, but it risks leaving the hearer with a burden of self-effort. Shifting the active verbs to God will transform this from a motivational speech into a gospel proclamation.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorically, this is an effective 'call to commitment'. Actantially, it reveals a structure where God is a tool for human success.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis might focus on the historical Jacob; Greimas shows how the preacher casts the *modern hearer* as the hero of the text.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas exposes that despite the 'homecoming' theme, the 'Sender' of the action is human anxiety, not divine decree.

appendices.notnotes: The sermon relies heavily on the 'Ad astra per aspera' motto, which is inherently anthropocentric and meritocratic.
